author: Karl Gernetzky
title: Aurora directors lose application to appeal | Mining
text:
Controversial businessman and nephew of President Jacob Zuma, Khulubuse Zuma, arrives for his uncle's inauguration ceremony at the Union Buildings in Pretoria in May. Picture: AFP PHOTO/POOL/MUJAHID SAFODIEN Related articles Hawks probe Aurora Empowerment Systems directors EDITORIAL: Aurora’s feckless directors Aurora liquidators set sights on President Jacob Zuma’s lawyer THE High Court in Pretoria on Friday denied an application from five former directors and investors of Aurora Empowerment Systems for leave to appeal a June ruling, leaving them personally liable for reckless management of the Pamodzi gold mines.
Trade union Solidarity has already appealed to the Pamodzi liquidators to begin sequestration proceedings against the five, which was necessary to bring justice and closure to hundreds of former employees, general secretary Gideon du Plessis said on Friday.
In June the court ruled that the Aurora directors — including former president Nelson Mandela’s grandson Zondwa Mandela, Thulani Ngubane, and President Jacob Zuma’s nephew Khulubuse Zuma — were liable for damages that could amount to R1.7bn.
The court found that the three men — along with investors Sulliman and Fazel Bhana — had acted recklessly and fraudulently when they assumed control of the Pamodzi group’s East Rand and Orkney gold mines in 2009.
The mines were idled and stripped of assets, leaving some 5,000 employees without pay for months.
Various legal teams representing the individuals have indicated they will approach the Supreme Court of Appeal, which must be done within three weeks, Mr du Plessis said.
But the sequestration process was not expected to be delayed by this, he said.
